docs.lead_paragraph: International The American and French Presidents hailed the British surrender at Yorktown in 1781 as the event that established the tradition of free, representative government in the West. But in careful, polite language the two leaders also indicated their differences over how the ideals of the American Revolution applied to the present. President Francois Mitterrand suggested that Washington should provide more support for the third world, while President Reagan stressed his goals of a smaller Government and a stronger military. (Page A1, Columns 4-5.) The Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded to Kenichi Fukui of Japan, whose work was neglected for decades, and to Roald Hoffmann of Cornell University, who developed a similar theory independently. Their work involves what is considered a major advance in applying the theories of quantum mechanics to predict the course of chemical reactions. (A1:2-4.)

docs.lead_paragraph: EVERYONE knows that drinking and driving is a dangerous mixture. But taking any of hundreds of prescribed drugs and driving may be equally dangerous, although that fact has gone largely unstudied and there have been few expressions of alarm. Unlike most other countries, Norway is doing something about the problem, and recent actions by the Scandinavian country may provide the impetus for other nations to follow its lead. Norwegian pharmacists have begun placing warning labels on many prescription drugs. In a few instances, there have been reports of jail sentences imposed on drivers whose judgment has been impaired by these drugs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Where the treatment seems worse than the disease, cancer patients may well avoid the treatment. As many as half at Duke Medical Center, for example, miss appointments or otherwise delay prescribed chemotherapy because of severe nausea or vomiting, staff physicians say.

docs.lead_paragraph: Andrew Silk, formerly a reporter for The Virginian-Pilot of Norfolk, Va., wrote ''A South African Shantytown: The Story of Modderdam,'' which was recently published in South Africa. By Andrew Silk ''Exhale, inhale, and hold your breath,'' a voice whispered over a microphone. The radiologist was taking a cross-section X-ray of my lung. I lay in the cradle of the computerized axial tomographer - the CAT scanner -with foam-rubber padding across my chest and a liquid sensitive to radiation dripping into a vein in my arm. In the control room, a technician pushed a button, and the cradle inched into a large metal tube. Like a salami in a delicatessen meat slicer, I passed slowly through the scanner. Five months earlier, I had lain in this cradle shortly after a malignant tumor had been discovered in my left lung. I did not know then if I could be treated. The tumor had since responded well to chemotherapy and radiation and had shrunk steadily. The violent cough it caused had almost disappeared.

docs.lead_paragraph: An experimental drug called metoclopromide can eliminate the nausea and vomiting that accompany one of the most widely used and powerful treatments for cancer, according to a team of researchers. The drug holds hope for other cancer patients suffering druginduced nausea and vomiting. These symptoms are ''the most frequent and debilitating acute side effects of chemotherapy for advanced cancer,'' the researchers wrote in the latest issue of The New England Journal of Medicine.
